sp.stage: (She takes hold of his hand, and as they are going, enter John, who pulls her.)

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: I'll lady you, with a vengeance, Mrs. Suſan; what, man, can't you be ſatisfied without my miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Lord MACGRINNON.
sp.p: Hoot, huſh, mon, your miſtreſs chuſes to go.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: But I don't chuſe it, I tell you, you ſarpent, you viper.

sp.speaker: Lord MACGRINNON.
sp.p: I never ſaw ſo rude a brute: is this the way you treat your miſtreſs, fellow?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Fellow yourſelf; why, 'tis becauſe ſhe is my miſtreſs that ſhe ſhan't go with thee; why, if thee beeſt a lord, thee beeſt only a man—and as an Engliſhman, I'm the beſt of the two, and ſo you ſhall find me, if you dare lay hold of her again.

sp.speaker: Lord MACGRINNON.
sp.p: He's certainly bewitch'd—ſpeak to him, ſweet love—

sp.speaker: SUSAN.
sp.p: Why, John— (In a low voice)

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: Why, zounds, I could tear your ugly eyes out, ſo I could (Sets down his lanthorn, and beats him with a ſtick) there—there—now, will you take my miſtreſs—

sp.speaker: Lord MACGRINNON.
sp.p: Help! help! murder!
sp.stage: [The group of company appear at the end of the ſtage with ſervants and torches, Mr. Camply runs up to John and holds his arm.]

sp.speaker: Mr. CAMPLY.
sp.p: What is the matter, my lord? what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Lord MACGRINNON.
sp.p: Why, Miſs Loveleſs and I were going to take a walk together, and that fellow is mad, I believe, for he will not let her do as ſhe likes.

sp.speaker: Mr. CAMPLY.
sp.p: Miſs Loveleſs! why, my lord, is this Miſs Loveleſs? you dream. (Holds the lanthorn up to Suſan's face.

sp.speaker: Lord MACGRINNON.
sp.p: Faith—an uglier dream by half—what in the name of wonder can all this be?

sp.speaker: BEVIL.
sp.p: This is a fine evening, my lord; but you look diſturb'd, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Lord MACGRINNON.
sp.p: Matter, why all the plagues of Egypt I believe: yes, yes, I am diſturb'd, and wet to the ſkin too; ſo pray what do you talk of a fine evening for, there has been a violent ſtorm of rain. (All the company laugh) Na, na—

sp.speaker: Miſs LOVELESS.
sp.p: I am much obliged to you, my lord, for your very kind intentions, and love of my fortune; I was ſo inſenſible of the nature of your affection, that it is to me you are indebted for that ſhower of rain from yonder engine, and for a beating into the bargain from honeſt John, who thought it was his miſtreſs you were going off with.

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p: What, and ſo you did not like him then—Ah! Suſan, Suſan, I've a month's mind never to be jealous again.

sp.speaker: SUSAN.
sp.p: Why, you great jolter-head you, did'ſt think I was going to run away; don't ye know that nothing but gentlefolks run away with one another?

sp.speaker: JOHN.
sp.p:
Well, well, ſay no more; if ever I am jealous again I wiſh a froſt may nip all the trees in the
garden; odſnigs, if Mr. Camply had not come, I believe in my heart I ſhould have broke every bone in your ſkin, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord MACGRINNON.
sp.p: Thank ye, I feel as if you had done it. Never did any man of the family of Macgrinnon ſuffer ſuch indignities as I have ſuffered from this company; to be deluded by a woman is a trifle; a man of ſenſe will expect it: but I canna help reflecting on the impertinencies, the jeers, and the ſluicing that have been thrown at me, without thinking that the happineſs of my noble anceſtors is diſturbed by the unworthy treatment that has been offered to their lineal deſcendant.

sp.speaker: Miſs LOVELESS.
sp.p: Certainly nothing but his vanity could induce him to think that I was weak enough to comply with his requeſt; and now, Miſs Camply, I will confeſs that I am much indebted to you for curing me of my ridiculous plan of conduct, and I wiſh you may ſucceed in every thing you undertake as you have in this.

sp.speaker: ELIZA.
sp.p:
Why, mine was rather a bold ſcheme, I muſt confeſs? but if the reſt of the company (bowing round) will forget what a very lively coxcomb I
have been, I ſhall not repent of the pains I have taken to pleaſe every one.

div.l: Ladies, I truſt you will adopt my plan,
And only wear the dreſs to gain the man.
